items.title: City Council to Examine Possible Mishandling of Rape Cases
items.abstract: A day after a report that DNA evidence may have been mishandled in 800 rape cases, the City Council announced it would hold an emergency hearing to look into the problem.

items.title: Company Defrauded City in Water Plant Work, Contractor Says
items.abstract: At a Bronx plant that has been plagued by problems, a firm is said to have evaded requirements on oversight by an electrician and on hiring companies owned by women or minorities.

items.title: A City Drenched in Sugar
items.abstract: New Orleans, where bakery loyalties run deep, has become a laboratory for desserts — especially when it comes to the popular king cake and its many variations.

items.title: 2 Campaign Aides Going on Trial, but Comptroller May Face Judgment
items.abstract: Court filings have already presented an unflattering portrait of the mayoral candidate Comptroller John C. Liu and his campaign finances.

items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: De Blasio to Announce New System Dedicated to Addressing Gun Crime in New York City
items.abstract: Starting this month, people charged with the possession of a firearm in the city will be sent to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which will preside over gun arrest cases.

items.title: Evictions in Walled Old City Stir Up a ‘Hornet’s Nest’
items.abstract: Palestinian residents of the Khaldiyya Ascent are facing eviction threats by Jewish organizations reclaiming properties they owned before Israel was established.

items.title: New York City Is Set to Adopt New Approach on Policing Minor Offenses
items.abstract: The measures would affect low-level offenses such as littering, public urination and public consumption of alcohol, in some cases removing them from the criminal justice system.

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: Mayor de Blasio Announces Plans to Boost Security and Mental Health Staff at New York City Shelters
items.abstract: The announcement came days after a killing at a shelter in Harlem, where a man with a history of psychiatric issues is suspected of fatally stabbing a former teacher.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: How New York City Ended Up With 2 Competing Women’s Marches
items.abstract: At issue is the question of inclusivity, one that has haunted the national movement since its inception.

items.title: New York City Food Carts Get Their First Report Cards
items.abstract: On Friday, the health department began issuing letter grades (most of them As) to street vendors. Reactions ranged from enthusiasm to shrugs.

items.title: Mayor’s Funeral Unites Gdansk. His Killing Exposed Poland’s Deep Divides.
items.abstract: Even before the mayor, Pawel Adamowicz, was laid to rest on Saturday, it was clear that his death could have profound political consequences.

items.title: Nathan Glazer, Urban Sociologist and Outspoken Intellectual, Dies at 95
items.abstract: Mr. Glazer often waded into heated debates over contentious issues about race, ethnicity, immigration and education.

items.title: Adrienne Adams Makes History as First Black N.Y.C. Council Speaker
items.abstract: Ms. Adams, who became speaker on Wednesday, will lead the most diverse City Council ever as New York tries to recover from the pandemic. She already faces battles with the mayor.

items.title: Eric Adams Ran on Making New York Safer. A Subway Killing Poses a Test.
items.abstract: The mayor, who made improving public safety a theme of his campaign, is dealing with the fallout from a high-profile death in Times Square.

items.title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
items.abstract: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.

items.title: Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Boston’s Refusal to Fly Christian Flag
items.abstract: The court seemed poised to rule that the city, which has approved many other requests to raise flags at its City Hall, violated a Christian group’s free speech rights.

items.title: The Art Design for Abolitionist Place in Brooklyn Moves Forward
items.abstract: Despite an ongoing legal challenge, New York City is going ahead with a plan for artwork at a new park that will feature messages of social justice, not the statuary some had sought.
